𝗪𝗵𝘆 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘄𝗲 𝘀𝗼 𝗼𝗯𝘀𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗱𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗲 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗯𝗲 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗲𝗻𝘁?

With constant noise pulling at your focus,
leaders don’t fail because they lack knowledge or resources
they fail because they aren’t fully there.

Here’s how to shift from overwhelmed to fully engaged, in just 7 mindful steps:

1️⃣ 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗠𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴
Focus on one thing at a time. Listen fully, act intentionally, and build trust through presence.

2️⃣ 𝗣𝗮𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗕𝗲𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴
Take a breath before responding to challenges.
A moment of calm leads to better choices.

3️⃣ 𝗦𝗲𝘁 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀
Start your day with clarity.
Ask yourself, “What kind of leader do I want to be today?”

4️⃣ 𝗣𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝗚𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝘁𝘂𝗱𝗲
Shift your focus from stress to growth by celebrating what’s working.

5️⃣ 𝗟𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻 𝗗𝗲𝗲𝗽𝗹𝘆
Silence your inner dialogue.
Be curious and open to truly understanding others.

6️⃣ 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗶𝘇𝗲 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘁
Leadership isn’t about hustling nonstop.
Recharge to show up at your best.

7️⃣ 𝗥𝗲𝗳𝗹𝗲𝗰𝘁 𝗗𝗮𝗶𝗹𝘆
Take 5 minutes at the end of your day to ask,
“What worked, and what can I improve?”

Mindful leadership isn’t about perfection.
It’s about progress.

Which one of these practices will you start today?
Let me know in the comments

postsData.content:
Ever wondered why sometimes large language models (LLMs) don’t respond how you expect? 

You phrase your prompt clearly. You think you're asking the right questions.

But somehow, the response feels… off.

️Maybe the AI is stuck in a loop.
️Or maybe it misunderstood your intent entirely.

Here’s a simple solution: Ask it to review and summarize the instructions you’ve given it.

You might think you’ve provided crystal-clear guidance, but have you? Or did the AI interpret it differently?

Try this approach:

→Ask the AI to summarize your instructions.
→Have it evaluate how well it’s following them.
→Adjust your communication style based on its response.

We often forget that LLMs are language models. The way we communicate with them defines their output.

A small tweak in phrasing can be the difference between a helpful response and a frustrating one.

Next time AI isn’t acting as expected, don’t assume it’s broken, assume it needs clearer guidance.

Struggling with AI adoption in your business? Change starts with how you interact with it. DM me to learn more or book your free strategy call in our website.

comments.commentText: Great tip! Clear communication is key to getting the AI responses you expect. Nerea Arregui Exposito

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Clear communication is key in working with LLMs. A few tweaks can lead to more effective interactions. Thanks for sharing!

postsData.content:
Graduated from UN Millennium Fellowship Class of 2024!!

Sachi Seva Foundation has been the brainchild of my parents. 

It all started during the summer of 2021, when the world was grappling with the second wave of COVID-19.

All of us were consumed with fear, doom, and uncertainty. People were dying, and hospitals were overcrowded with patients.

The situation became so grim that family members couldn’t even cremate the dead bodies of their loved ones.

That’s when my parents decided to act — someone had to do something. What started as helping our neighbours, grew into hundreds and thousands.

They decided to step out from their homes and distribute masks, sanitizers and food to everyone for free of cost.

Eventually my father was being recognised as the “Langer waale Sardar Ji” (translation: the Sardar who distributes free food). His turban became a symbol of hope and change.

It became a part of our routine to distribute free food every Sunday. We continued this even after the pandemic ended.

In 2023, we decided that our efforts need more recognition so that the impact can be 100x.

That’s when the name, Sachi Seva was christened.

Everything was going good but we weren’t satisfied. We realised that we can’t handle everything- from social media to helping people on ground level. We need more help.

Finally in 2025, we have decided to hire people. We are looking for video editors and content strategists, who can handle the Instagram account of our collective.

Check the comment box for detailed description on the roles.

My parents have passed the baton of leadership to me and I want to do justice to their work. Come and join me as we create ripple effects of change.

Also, it is a UN recognised project now so brownie points for that

postsData.content:
9 Speaking Rules To Command Any Room
(and be heard, respected, and remembered)

The leaders we admire most,
Craft their words with surgical precision.

Their influence isn't natural.
They follow specific rules that most people don't know.

Here's your playbook to become an unforgettable speaker:

1. The "Three Levels Up" Rule
↳ Filter every detail through this lens:
"Does it matter three levels up?"
↳ If not, save it for the documentation
↳ Keep your message strategically focused

2. The "Silence Sandwich" Strategy
↳ Pause 3 seconds before & after your key message
↳ Watch attention spike, memory deepen
↳ Simple technique, executive impact

3. The "30-70 Rule"
↳ 30% data, 70% strategic narrative
↳ Turn information into inspiration
↳ Keep your audience invested, not overwhelmed

4. The "Elevator First" Framework
↳ Distill your message to 30 words
↳ Lead with it, even in hour-long presentations
↳ Everything else supports this core message

5. "Active Engagement"
↳ Read the room every 5 minutes
↳ Engagement dropping? Pivot to discussion
↳ Keep control through connection

6. "Message Echo"
↳ Circle back to your core message every 10 minutes
↳ Reinforce your strategic thread
↳ Build lasting impact

7. "What-So What-Now What"
↳ Present the insight
↳ Share the strategic importance
↳ Drive clear action

8. The "High-Stakes Opener"
↳ Start with your most powerful insight
↳ Lead with what matters most
↳ Everything else amplifies your opening

9. The "Clarity Check"
↳ If you can't say it in one breath, simplify
↳ Sharp thinking creates sharp speaking
↳ Impact comes from clarity

Your words either add weight or waste time.
Choose wisely.

Who’s the best speaker you’ve seen - and why?

️ Share and support your network.
 Followfor impactful leadership insights.

comments.commentText: Commanding a room isn’t a gift, it’s a skill. These techniques separate forgettable speakers from the truly influential. Meera Remani

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! The Silence Sandwich is a game changer. Effective speaking is an art—every leader should master these rules! 🗣️💡

postsData.content:
For post 22 in the series, I’d love to hear some stories on how your company or organization is witnessing the impact of potential 
#tariffs from Mexico or Canada.

The magnitude of the sheer potential of 25% tariffs of Mexico has already caused a massive restructure in an outdoor company I’m very familiar with, as their product was made in Mexico, they couldn’t pass a tariff that size onto their customers- since the purchase orders were written months before the tariffs were announced- and effectively every piece of product brought in would be sold with no profit margin. I doubt they are the only company experiencing this.

It’s another story for product that’s ordered consistently, where prices can fluctuate and suppliers can simply raise prices. Doesn’t mean that price will stick, unless there are limited alternatives. Think
. Mexico represents 40+% of the international market. Here are some other categories:

What are you all seeing out there? This is about to get very interesting, even if the tariffs don’t end up being imposed for long.

comments.commentText:
Right now, what I can share is my perspective on how tariffs might affect the retail shoe market, particularly independent comfort footwear stores.

For SKUs manufactured in Mexico or China, I believe a 25% tariff will translate directly into higher retail prices. Based on my calculations—factoring in ex-factory cost, load (tariff and transportation), wholesale margin, and retailer margin—a shoe that was previously selling for around $90 at retail will now likely be priced at $115 or more.

We can do similar illustations on higher priced footwear, for Canada.

Beyond the immediate price increase, both wholesalers and retailers may consider taking a higher margin as a precautionary measure. The concern is that this initial 25% tariff could escalate further due to the ongoing political and diplomatic strategies that may lead to tit-for-tat tariff adjustments. in those tariffs. If that happens, businesses may need to adjust margins further to maintain profitability and manage uncertainty. Unfortunately, some consumer sales will decline if prices become too high.

postsData.commentAdded: This is a crucial topic! Many companies are navigating tough decisions amid uncertainty. Excited to hear more stories and insights from others!

✪ Alejandro Quinones
✪ Alejandro Quinones
postsData.content:
I worked across diverse markets and learned that expanding into Mexico is about embracing local culture and building strong relationships!


Since joiningin Mexico, I’ve gained valuable insights into what it takes to navigate this rapidly growing economy and connect with stakeholders.


Here’s what has worked for me:

- Focus on relationships first
Business is built on trust here. Take time to meet people, build rapport and don’t rush the process: it pays off 

- Breakfast meetings = better results
Early morning, informal breakfast meetings often lead to more productive conversations

- Patience is KEY
Mexican business culture is a mix of flexibility and formality: be patient with timing, and respect local customs ️

- Hierarchy matters
In Mexico, seniority matters: in meetings make sure you bring the right people to the table

- Stay accessible via WhatsApp
Emails are great but WhatsApp is where the real action happens: be ready to respond quickly 

- Dress smart & adapt to the heat
Always look professional but remember the weather: it’s not all about suits when it’s 30°C!


With the economy booming and Mexico emerging as a key global player, understanding the local culture and adapting your approach is critical for success!


Are you considering expanding into Mexico or are you already doing business here? 

———

comments.commentText: Adapting to local culture is key—whether it’s embracing WhatsApp or learning the art of breakfast meetings, it’s all about building trust

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Emphasizing relationships and cultural adaptability resonates. Looking forward to seeing more success stories from your journey in Mexico! 🌟

◾ Web 4.0: The Future Beyond Decentralization ◾ 
 
We’ve all heard about Web 3.0 - blockchain, decentralization, and user ownership. But what comes next?

Welcome to Web 4.0 - where AI, automation, and hyper-personalized experiences redefine how we interact with the digital world. If Web 3.0 gave us ownership, Web 4.0 gives us intelligence - a seamless connection between the real and virtual worlds, driven by AI-powered agents.

 What Makes Web 4.0 Different?
1. AI-Driven Experiences
Web 4.0 will be powered by intelligent AI agents that don’t just respond - they anticipate. Imagine a digital assistant that books your flights, manages your finances, and even negotiates deals before you ask.

2. Seamless Integration Between Digital & Physical
The line between the real and digital worlds will blur. AR, VR, and AI-driven systems will create environments where shopping, work, and entertainment feel like an extension of reality.

3. Beyond Decentralization - Autonomous Networks
Web 3.0 gave us decentralization, but Web 4.0 takes it further with self-governing digital ecosystems. AI-driven smart contracts will operate without human input, making processes faster and more secure.

4. Self-Learning, Personalized Internet
Imagine a web that adapts to you - learning from your actions and tailoring everything from content to services based on your unique needs. No more mindless scrolling - only relevant, real-time insights.

5. New Opportunities for Startups
Web 4.0 will unlock trillions in new market value, with AI-first businesses leading the way. The companies that integrate AI-powered agents, automation, and blockchain will dominate the next era of the internet.

 How Can You Leverage Web 4.0?
The future isn’t coming - it’s already here. Are you ready? If you're a startup founder, this is your golden opportunity. AI-driven businesses are scaling faster than traditional ones. The key is understanding how to integrate Web 4.0 tech into your startup - before your competitors do.

That's where we come in. At Brainz, we help founders launch, scale, and dominate in the Web 4.0 era. With over two decades of experience building, scaling, and automating startups across industries like Fintech, Blockchain, AI, and eCommerce, we understand the intricacies of the digital landscape. Our mission is to empower businesses of all sizes to harness the power of artificial intelligence to drive growth and efficiency.

Write us atto transform your startup into a $20M enterprise within 24 months.

The future isn't coming - it's already here. Are you ready?

High Performance Starts With Emotional Regulation 

One of the biggest factors in achieving high performance isn’t just skill or strategy, it’s mastering emotional regulation. I believe this makes up 90% of personal development.

We, as humans, are deeply emotional creatures. Our emotions evolved for survival, triggering responses that once kept us safe in the wild. But today, those same emotions often hold us back, not from predators, but from opportunities, challenges, and growth.

A study published in Psychology Today reveals that one of the biggest reasons people avoid taking risks is the fear of uncertainty, even when those risks could lead to personal development. (Find link below)

Think about that for a second. How many times have you hesitated, not because you weren’t capable, but because you feared the unknown?
Emotional regulation isn’t about suppressing emotions. It’s about developing the awareness to respond intentionally, rather than reacting impulsively.

postsData.content:
“How are you today?”
 
If I could eliminate one vomit-inducing phrase from your BDR’s script, THIS would be it!

Your BDR’s job is to grab attention and spark curiosity on a cold call (or a warm call).

If you start with that awful starter, you’ve lost that opportunity.

It’s like trying to start a fire with a soggy match.

Why? Because we humans KNOW that this overused question means there is a seller on the other end of the phone.

And we don’t like to be sold to!

The alternative? Master the 10-second hook.

(Even better – make it a 5-second hook!)

How?

1. Review real scenarios from your ICP’s pain points
2. Give each BDR 10 seconds to grab attention and spark curiosity on a cold call.
3. Make it a competition. Vote on the most compelling hooks as a team.

In a world of endless noise, prospects decide within seconds if they’ll stay on the line.

Let’s make sure your BDRs nail that critical opening moment.

Happy selling!
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! A strong opener is key to engagement. Excited to see how teams transform their approach to spark curiosity! #SalesStrategies

Job Seekers - your LinkedIn About section should 𝗡𝗢𝗧 be AI-generated buzz words.

Here's what it should say  

First - I want to remind you of something my coach taught me.

Facts tell.

Stories sell.

When you're seeking a job you're selling a product.

And 𝗬𝗢𝗨 are the product.

Here's some examples of things you 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱𝗻'𝘁 do:

 Writing in the third person to describe yourself.

 Writing cliche buzz phrases like "streamlining operational efficiency."

 An exhaustive list of certifications & degrees.

It sounds like everyone else.

It's uninspiring.

And it falls flat with your audience.

The About section is your opportunity to tell a story.

It's where you differentiate yourself from everyone else's cliche, buzzword-filled profile.

Here's what it 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 say:

 What's unique about you.

 A pivotal moment in your life that led you to where you are now.

 Who you can help.

Here's an example to iterate from,

postsData.content:
8 Reasons You’re Not Behind in Life 

(And How to Stop Thinking You Are)

Do you ever feel like you're behind where you "should" be in life? You're not alone. It's easy to fall into the comparison trap, judging your progress against others.

But the truth is, you're not behind at all.

Here are 8 reasons why:

1/ Your timeline is unique to you
↳ Comparing your progress to others’ is a recipe for frustration.
↳ Everyone moves at their own pace - trust your journey.

2/ Growth isn’t always visible
↳ Some growth happens behind the scenes.
↳ You’re always evolving, even when it’s not obvious to others.

3/ Life doesn’t follow a set path
↳ Success isn’t linear - there are many roads to the same destination.
↳ Flexibility and adaptation are key to thriving, not following someone else’s rules.

4/ You’ve already made progress
↳ It’s easy to forget how far you’ve come when you focus on where you want to be.
↳ Take time to celebrate how much you’ve achieved so far.

5/ Failures don’t define you
↳ Setbacks are lessons, not roadblocks.
↳ Each failure brings you closer to success - embrace them as growth opportunities.

6/ Time is relative
↳ You don’t have to have everything figured out by a certain age.
↳ Life is a marathon, not a sprint - take it at your own pace.

7/ There’s no "perfect" time
↳ Waiting for the "perfect" moment to start something can keep you stuck.
↳ The right time is always now - take the first step today.

8/ You’re where you need to be
↳ Life unfolds as it’s meant to, and your path is uniquely yours.
↳ Trust that you’re on the right track, even if you can’t see the entire journey yet.

The only person you should compare yourself to is you. How have you grown? What are you proud of? Progress takes patience, persistence and self-compassion. You've got this.

Remember: You’re not behind - you’re exactly where you need to be.

What part of your journey are you proud of?

️ Please repost to help others.

 Follow mefor daily posts on mental health and personal development.

postsData.content:
From winning leadership awards early to learning what leadership actually means decades later...

From elementary school through university, I collected leadership awards.

Back then, I thought being a leader was about being decisive and loud– charting a path, making decisions, and telling people what to do.

Looking back now, I sometimes cringe thinking about it... I was not a leader – I was just a loud kid who refused to follow directions I didn't agree with.

Fast forward to today, after years of researching and working with industry experts and work-culture leaders, my perspective has completely transformed.

Leadership isn't about standing out or charging ahead. It's not about being the loudest or most commanding voice in the room.

It isn't about you at all.

True leadership is about empowering others to thrive.

It's about listening—really listening—and creating the space for others to grow, collaborate, and succeed.

The data backs this up:

86% of employees who received meaningful feedback in the last week are fully engaged—compared to just 23% of workers overall. Active listening itself can increase collaboration and productivity by up to 25%.

Even more telling: 80% of workplace conflicts stem from poor communication. But when leaders focus on active listening, employee satisfaction jumps by 30%.

Over the years, I've learned three things little Jean didn't appreciate that actually transform bosses into inspiring and impactful leaders:

 Listen first, ask second.
Leadership isn't about having all the answers—it's about understanding the questions. Active listening helps leaders uncover what their team truly needs to thrive.

 Empower, don't control.
A leader's role is to bring out the best in others. This means assigning roles based on strengths, providing the resources to set them up for success, and trusting your people to do great work.

 Model collaboration.
Great leaders show their teams how to work together by practicing collaboration themselves—valuing diverse perspectives and making space for every voice at the table.

At Octopy, we bring this philosophy to life through human-focused leadership workshops, keynote speaking, and custom programming.

What's one lesson that's transformed your understanding of leadership?

Let's talk about it in the comments—I'd love to hear your thoughts.

DeepSeek proved that powerful models don’t need to break the bank. By delivering results comparable to OpenAI's models at 3% of the cost, they’ve challenged the idea that bigger budgets always mean better AI.

◼️ 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗜 𝗶𝗻𝗱𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘆?

postsData.content:
"It can't be that simple."

Well, yes. Actually it can...

See waaay back when I started as a product marketer in b2b tech, I had a problem.

→ As a product marketer, you're the expert in the product...
→ AND you're the the expert in the audience.
→ Because your job is to connect the two.

You'd think a product marketer in b2b tech -- 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘥𝘦𝘧𝘪𝘯𝘦𝘥 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘦𝘳𝘵 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘥𝘶𝘤𝘵 -- would have to be technical.

How else could you become the expert in a technical product?

But me? I had about as much technical talent as a crayon.

Did that stop me? HELL NO!

I leaned in on what I knew from back in my college days.

Ancient Greek Philosophy.

Aristole defined the ESSENCE of something as "the what it was to be."

I figured if I could get to the essence of the product, starting with the deepest level features and working my way up, then I could understand the product at its core.

I could get to its essence.

That's when I came up with the three big rock questions at the center of everything I do today, working with founders and marketers to create their own killer messaging that attracts more of the right buyers.

What I've learned after practicing this technique for more than 20 years is this:

When you get to the essence of something, somethign cool happens.

→ Explaining it
→ Drawing analogies to it
→ Creating content about it

...all becomes second nature.

Because you understand it at its essence, you have the building blocks to create messaging that hits the mark no matter the audience, no matter the situation.

I dove into all this a bit on the first episode of the newpodcast with my main man,.

Here's a peek.

Listen to to entire episode TOMORROW (!!) wherever you dig podcasts.
postsData.commentAdded: Love this perspective! Getting to the essence truly transforms how we communicate and connect. Excited to listen to the podcast!

The secret to great marketing is simple:

Guess and test.

Every successful campaign starts as a shot in the dark.

I learned this over five years of hard knocks.

Your first ad won't work.

Your first copy won't convert.

Your first offer won't sell.

But each test teaches you something new:

• Which headlines grab attention
• Which offers people want
• Which audiences buy

Testing gives you clear data on what works.

That’s why the brands that win aren't those with the biggest budgets.

They're the fastest at finding what works.

So stop planning and start testing.

Launch that "bad" landing page.

Run that "weak" ad.

Send that "rough" email copy.

Double down on your winners and cut your losers fast.

That's the whole game.

Test more = Win more

7 Brutal truths you’re trapped in golden handcuffs:

(Most don’t realize until it’s too late.)

→ The salary is great.
→ The benefits are solid.
→ The lifestyle is comfortable.

So why does it feel like a trap?

Because security can be deceiving.

What looks like stability might be stagnation.

Here’s how to know if you’re stuck:

1️⃣ You dread Mondays but stay for the benefits

↳ The thought of work makes you anxious.
↳ But the perks feel too good to leave.

2️⃣ Your skills are stagnating

↳ You haven’t learned anything new in months.
↳ But the bonuses make it feel worth it.

3️⃣ You’re overqualified for your role

↳ You could do your job in your sleep.
↳ But the pay cheque keeps you from seeking a challenge.

4️⃣ Your values don’t align with the company

↳ You disagree with key decisions.
↳ But the stock options keep you silent.

5️⃣ You’ve turned down dream opportunities

↳ Exciting roles come up.
↳ But none match your current package.

6️⃣ Your health is suffering

↳ The stress is affecting your well-being.
↳ But the benefits are too good to leave.

7️⃣ You’re staying out of fear

↳ The thought of a pay cut terrifies you.
↳ As your lifestyle has expanded to match your income.

Golden handcuffs don’t feel heavy until you try to take them off.

→ Routine replaces ambition.
→ Fear replaces growth.
→ Security replaces freedom.

A high salary means nothing if it comes at the cost of your time, health and purpose.

Remember: As you grow and evolve, your work life will also grow and evolve.

- - -

P.S. Would you take a pay cut for a job that excites you?

 𝐈𝐧𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞 𝐓𝐚𝐱 𝐑𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐟:  The new tax regime now offers 𝐳𝐞𝐫𝐨 𝐭𝐚𝐱 𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐧𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞  𝐮𝐩 𝐭𝐨 ₹12 𝐥𝐚𝐤𝐡𝐬, thanks to rebate benefits under Section 87A.

 𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐒𝐞𝐧𝐢𝐨𝐫 𝐂𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐳𝐞𝐧𝐬 & 𝐋𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐥𝐨𝐫𝐝𝐬:: TDS exemption limits have been raised – 𝒇𝒓𝒐𝒎 ₹50,000 𝒕𝒐 ₹1 𝒍𝒂𝒌𝒉 𝒐𝒏 𝒊𝒏𝒕𝒆𝒓𝒆𝒔𝒕 𝒊𝒏𝒄𝒐𝒎𝒆 𝒂𝒏𝒅 𝒇𝒓𝒐𝒎 ₹2.4 𝒍𝒂𝒌𝒉 𝒕𝒐 ₹6 𝒍𝒂𝒌𝒉 𝒐𝒏 𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒂𝒍 𝒊𝒏𝒄𝒐𝒎𝒆.

 𝐈𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐒𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐨𝐫 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: FDI in insurance increased to 100% (with a condition that premium investments remain within India). A huge push for financial inclusion!

 𝐒𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐆𝐢𝐠 𝐄𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐨𝐦𝐲: Gig workers will now be recognized officially and brought under the Jan Arogya health insurance scheme. A step towards social security for this growing workforce!

postsData.content:
"Aakanksha, you’re your own boss, so lucky man!"

That’s something I hear from friends every time they’re complaining about their 9-to-5 grind.

Don’t get me wrong, I love my work. Most days, I’m all in. But let’s be real—there are tough days too.

After a few years of doing this, I’ve learned how to hack the system. Here's what’s helped me keep my sanity:

- 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗗𝗼𝘂𝗯𝘁: No senior to guide you? No problem. I set clear goals, track my own progress, and always have a backup plan. Pro tip: start small and build from there.

- 𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁: When you’re the boss, the concept of "personal time" blurs. To stay on track without burning out, I set work hours, create a dedicated workspace, and use a calendar system.

- 𝗘𝘅𝗵𝗮𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: Doing everything yourself can drain you. I’ve learned to take short breaks after each task and occasionally outsource work to focus on what truly matters.

- 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗙𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗴𝘂𝗲: Being the only creative brain behind your business can get tiring. When I hit a wall, I step away—whether it’s a walk, a nap, or blasting some music. Trust me, it works.

- 𝗙𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹 𝗣𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲: Early on, income was inconsistent, and the cash flow stress was real. I diversified my income and created a financial cushion to manage the ups and downs.

Yes, being self-employed can feel like a one-woman show. It can be exhausting, but honestly? I wouldn’t have it any other way!

comments.commentText: Aakanksha Monga Absolutely! Being your own boss is rewarding but comes with its own challenges. In Western India, especially in cities like Pune and Nashik, I’ve seen many entrepreneurs, from independent filmmakers to digital marketers, face similar struggles. For instance, in Maharashtra’s growing start-up scene, founders juggle creative fatigue and financial uncertainty daily. A filmmaker in Kolhapur once told me that stepping away to explore nature helped him break creative blocks—something I relate to when writing. Whether it’s setting clear work boundaries or diversifying income, the key is to embrace the journey, knowing that every challenge shapes us into better leaders.

postsData.commentAdded: Thanks for sharing, Aakanksha! Your insights on self-management and balancing the challenges of entrepreneurship are truly valuable. Keep thriving!

Linkedin filters my followers so I dont have to

Every 3 months, I lose 500 to 600 followers.

And honestly?
I’m fine with that.

Some people see unfollows as a bad thing.

I see them as LinkedIn doing me a favor.

Why?

Because followers aren’t valuable unless they’re engaged.

I’d rather have a smaller, highly interested community

Than a bloated audience that’s only here for the ride.

If you’re afraid of losing followers,

Ask yourself,

Are they adding value to your network?

Or just taking up space?

Growth isn’t just about numbers.
It’s about real connections.
The right followers stick.
The wrong ones leave.
That’s how it should be.

So, every time I lose 500 followers,

I see it as LinkedIn saying,

Let me clean up your room a bit.

And just like that,

I’m left with people who care about leadership, business, and progress.

The kind of people I actually want to talk to.

 PRO TIP

postsData.content:
Harnessing the Power of the Halo Effect in Marketing 

The best marketers know this powerful psychology concept: the Halo Effect.


Here’s the magic:

1. A positive view of one brand aspect.
2. Leads to a positive view of the whole brand.


Picture this in a hotel:

- You walk into a stunning lobby and think, "Wow."
- Naturally, you assume the rooms are equally impressive.


Smart hotels utilize strong visuals to shape guest perceptions.

You can do the same in marketing.
- Skip overloading with details.
- Focus on strong symbols that shape perceptions.


It's not about more messages.


It's about highlighting the right ones.


---

postsData.content:
4 Skills That Helped Me Build Genuine Connections with My Network 


When I started networking, I struggled to make meaningful connections. I used to think networking was just about exchanging business cards or sending connection requests.

But over time, I realized that real connections are built through trust, value, and authenticity.

Here are 4 skills that helped me build strong and genuine relationships:


1. Active Listening

I used to focus more on what to say next rather than truly listening. But when I started paying attention, asking follow-up questions, and showing genuine interest, conversations became deeper and more meaningful.

- Studies show that good listeners are 40% more likely to build strong relationships because people feel valued and heard.


2. Being Helpful Without Expectations

Instead of reaching out only when I needed something, I started offering help—whether it was sharing a resource, giving feedback, or introducing people to the right connections.

According to research, people who give without expecting immediate returns build stronger long-term networks.


3. Sharing My Experiences Openly

I used to hesitate to share my struggles and lessons, thinking they weren’t valuable. But when I started sharing my journey—both wins and failures—I noticed more people resonated with me.

Authenticity creates trust, and trust builds meaningful connections.


4. Emotional Intelligence (EQ)

I worked on understanding people’s emotions, responding with empathy, and adapting my communication style.

Research shows that people with high EQ are 3x more successful in building lasting relationships because they make others feel understood and valued.


Remember, Networking isn’t just about numbers; it’s about genuine relationships that grow over time.


Do you agree?

Followfor more.

comments.commentText: Swati Mathur Absolutely agree, Swati! Genuine connections are all about authenticity and value. Active listening, offering help without expecting anything in return, and sharing your journey are such powerful ways to foster real relationships. Emotional intelligence truly is a game-changer when it comes to understanding others and building trust. Thanks for sharing these insights—it's a reminder that networking is about meaningful interactions, not just numbers!

postsData.content:
Why are you so serious all the time?


I rarely post about what I do professionally.

Why?

Because I think the majority of people aren’t reading that.

Most content infuses something work related.

Very few actually make it entertaining.

People are not here just to learn about what you do.

I’d argue even that most might not actually care.

The majority that consume content are doing so

-> for entertainment
-> to find a prospect
-> to earn some cool

Most content isn’t read, it’s skimmed at best.

Most posts aren’t entertaining, they push a narrative.

Most people aren’t here for you, they’re here for themselves.

There’s not enough humor, at least that I see.

Maybe people are funny?

There’s not enough real stories and anectodes.

You know when people continue to show up for you daily?

It’s not the reciprocity loop of like and comment exchanges.

It’s when they get a true sense of who you are, not what you do.

In all the calls I’ve had that were generated from

No one ever had a clue as to what I did

but almost everyone always had a really good sense of who I was.

Yours truthfully,

comments.commentText: I love this post Michael Kainatsky and yes people do get a sense of who you are from your post here. This made me laugh out loud. Thanks for the levity to start my week. A great way to do it brother. I'm going to use this somehow with your permission.

Busy vs. Productive: Are You Investing Your Time Wisely?  

There’s a big difference between staying busy with clients and actually achieving the results you deserve. The key questions to ask:

 What are you busy doing?
 Who are you doing it for?
 Is this the best use of your time?

Yes, that order might need your attention—but is it from an ideal client or just one of the many small accounts that demand extra hand-holding, end up on the rework list, or always push for a discount?

Take a step back. Focus on high-value clients that contribute meaningfully to your business, not just the ones keeping you "busy."

postsData.content:
Your brand truth doesn't change with each generation.

The way you show it does.

I keep seeing brands create entirely different personalities for different age groups.

One voice for Gen Z. Another for Millennials. A third for Gen X.

That's not cross-generational marketing.

That's brand schizophrenia.

The core of your brand - what you stand for - should resonate across generations. It's the manifestation that evolves.

Take sustainability, for example:

- Gen X responds to environmental legacy
- Millennials engage with systemic change
- Gen Z gravitates toward collective action

Same truth. Different expressions.

The strongest brands I've worked with don't shape-shift between generations.

They translate their core message into different cultural languages.

When we focus on translation rather than transformation, our message becomes clearer.

Our impact grows stronger.

Our brand builds true cross-generational resonance.

comments.commentText: Absolutely agree, it's crucial to stay true to the brand's core values across generations.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! A unified brand truth, expressed in relatable ways, fosters deeper connections across generations. Its about resonance, not rhetoric!

postsData.content:
You’ve already done harder things than asking a client for more money.

Want proof?

Starting out, I was terrified of revealing the price.

And when I did, it was a shifting landscape.

They balk at the number? Oh, no worries, “What sounds fair?”

I did this for a decade +.

Now, I work with clients all around the world who are charging five figures per month without fear.

How the hell can someone who was terrified to do that help others feel confident enough to do it?

A tiny shift happened in my mind.

And it changed everything for me, and can for you (if you let it):

Money is so common that they keep printing more of it. Value is uncommon. Provide immense value. Charge what you want.

People value value.

Odd, right?

But it’s how my clients have gone from:

→ Charging hourly to not accepting less than $5K per deal
→ Going from rev share only to five-figures/mo + rev share
→ Adding value to an existing offer to bring in $91K in the next 12 months



People who, 30 days earlier, didn’t believe it was possible adopted the “money is common + value is uncommon” principle and started getting paid their MF’ing worth.

My business is one month old, and so far, my clients have contracted an extra $125K to their businesses.

I charge for the value they get. And so do they.

Life is beautiful.

P.S. Agency owner who’s charging hourly for your work?

Hugz. Follow me, and I’ll send daily stuff that’ll help you get out of that pain. And again…hugz.

P.P.S.  you know they closed it

Still can be a challenge to believe in, but makes it easier to do so.

Artificial Intelligence Investors Group: Robotics, Machine Learning, NLP, Computer Vision & IoT
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 4 – Update Agent LEARNING
 Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (all links in my comment below)

A report in Quanta magazine provides an example: The idea of a “bank” has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. “It’s more abstract, really different from what you’re seeing,” said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3 of this series.

In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not “know” anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights! The contrast between human learning and LLM processes truly highlights the potential of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem. Excited for Part 5!
